text:
“I am bad, I know that,” he thought to himself, feeling ashamed right after he had been angry with Dounia. “But why do they care about me if I don’t deserve it? Oh, if only I were alone and no one loved me, and I had never loved anyone! None of this would have happened. But I wonder, will I become so humble in fifteen or twenty years that I will bow down to people and cry about being a criminal? Yes, that’s it, that’s what they want. Look at them running around the streets, every one of them a bad person at heart and, even worse, a fool. But if I try to get away with it, they would be furious. Oh, how I hate them all!”

He started to think about how he could be made to feel small before all of them, without exception—made small by being found guilty. And yet, why not? It must be so. Wouldn’t twenty years of being trapped break him completely? Water can wear down stone. And why should he live after that? Why should he go now when he knew it would be like this? He had asked himself that question many times since the night before, but still, he went.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The protagonist grapples with feelings of guilt and resentment towards those who love him, questioning the nature of his punishment and the inevitability of his humiliation.
